newsitem.title: USA: Dollar ends volatile week on quiet note.
newsitem.headline: Dollar ends volatile week on quiet note.

text.p: The dollar ended a volatile week on a quiet note Friday, closing lower against other major currencies in thin, pre-holiday trading, dealers said.

A looming three-day holiday weekend in the two largest foreign exchange markets -- the United States and Britain -- and an early Friday close in most U.S. asset and derivative markets subdued trading volume and activity, dealers said.
The dollar fell to 115.65 yen by the close from 116.13 on Thursday and fell to 1.6930 marks from 1.6945.
Stealing the spotlight was a sudden overnight drop in the Australian dollar, which shed over a full cent on news of an unexpected cut in official Australian interest rates.

The Reserve Bank of Australia surprised the markets by chopping 0.5 percentage point off the official cash rate, the fourth cut since last July, pushing the rate to 5.5 percent -- its lowest since August 1994.
The Australian dollar closed at $0.7670, down from $0.7775 at Thursday's close.
The dollar showed little reaction to remarks overnight from Japanese Ministry of Finance official Eisuke Sakakibara, who was interviewed by French newspaper Le Monde.
Sakakibara said that a rise in Japan's discount rate should be expected by the end of the year.
"The discount rate is currently very low. If it rises by 0.5 percent, it will be at 1.0 percent, which remains low. A move on such a scale should be expected in the coming year," he said.
He also noted, however, that he did not believe the Bank of Japan would raise rates before it was sure of a solid economic upturn.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Norwest Corp., agreed with Sakakibara and said he expects official Japanese interest rates to be hiked sometime this summer.
"Economic growth is clearly gaining some momentum. Economic conditions are better than a lot of people realise in Japan right now and that should lead to higher interest rates," he said.

The first round of French parliamentary elections take place this weekend. Analysts said victory for the ruling centre-right coalition -- the expected outcome -- would bolster the dollar against the mark as the French franc should respond favourably. But a left-wing win could hurt the U.S. unit as dealers buy marks.

"With the French elections this weekend, there is some anticipation that there may be a risk that the Socialists will get in. People have bought short-dated options that give them the right to own marks," said Russell LaScala, chief dealer at Citibank.
"It's a good risk-reward, low premium, high return option," he added.
Elsewhere, the dollar fell to 1.4033 Swiss francs from 1.4150 francs and the British pound recovered from Thursday's sell-off to end higher at $1.6347 from $1.6240.
The dollar gained to Canadian $1.3747 from C$1.3733.
